title: 108_hr5319
content: The Act titled "Renewable Energy Financing Incentive Act of 2004" allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon the subsequent purchase of renewable energy property under section 1046 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property if renewable energy property is acquired within the replacement period. Gain will only result to the extent that the sale price exceeds the cost of the renewable energy property acquired. "In the case of acquiring renewable energy property, gain is recognized when the sale price exceeds the cost of the property. This gain is recognized except as provided in this section. Renewable energy property refers to facilities in the US using renewable sources for electricity generation or fuel manufacturing." The term 'renewable energy property' refers to facilities in the US using renewable sources for electricity generation or fuel manufacturing. Special rules apply to partnerships and corporations involved in owning or operating such property. The term 'replacement period' refers to a 2-year period after the sale of real property with an election under subsection (a). Property received by the taxpayer must be identified for the purposes of this section. Cooperatives are subject to rules similar to partnerships and corporations owning renewable energy property. The replacement period is a 2-year period after the sale of real property with an election under subsection (a). Property received must be identified within 180 days after the transfer of the relinquished property. The basis of renewable energy property is the same as the exchanged property, adjusted for money received and gain or loss recognized. The basis of renewable energy property is the same as the exchanged property, adjusted for money received and gain or loss recognized. If a taxpayer disposes of renewable energy property, any unrecognized gain will be recognized. The gain not recognized under subsection (a) for acquiring renewable energy property is not taken into account in certain dispositions, such as after the taxpayer's death, in a compulsory conversion before the threat, or if the disposition aimed to avoid federal income tax. There is a statute of limitations for realizing any gain. The statute of limitations for assessing deficiencies on gains from the sale of renewable energy property under subsection (a) is 3 years from the date the taxpayer notifies the Secretary of the cost of purchasing such property. The deficiency regarding gain from the sale of renewable energy property must not expire before 3 years from the taxpayer notifying the Secretary of the cost of purchasing such property, their intention not to purchase, or failure to make the purchase within the replacement period. This deficiency can be assessed before the 3-year period ends, despite any laws preventing such assessment. The deficiency in gain from the sale of renewable energy property can be assessed within 3 years of notifying the Secretary about the purchase cost or intention not to purchase, despite any legal barriers. Amendments are made to the tax code to accommodate this provision. Amendments are made to the tax code to allow for the nonrecognition of gain on the sale of property under certain conditions. Amendments to the tax code allow for nonrecognition of gain from the sale of real property upon subsequent purchase of renewable energy property, effective for real property sold after December 31, 2004.
